title: Jaeseok Hwang
text:
Hi, I’m Jaeseok Hwang, a Ph.D. candidate in Agricultural and Consumer Economics (ACE)  at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign (UIUC), with an expected graduation in May 2025. Over the past 5 years, I have gained extensive experience as a research assistant for the USDA NRCS-funded project, “Data Intensive Farm Management.” 
In this role, I worked extensively with large-scale datasets, applying advanced data analytics and statistical techniques to address complex questions in farm management and productivity. During this time, I developed a deep expertise in designing and running machine-learning-based regression models to derive actionable insights from big data. My analytical toolkit includes a professional level of proficiency in R, which I use for most of my data processing, statistical modeling, and visualization tasks, as well as Python, which I employ as a versatile second option for complementary analysis and machine learning workflows.
This website highlights my research journey, showcasing programming code (R and Python via VS Code), summary of research outputs, and my individual research note reflecting my knowledge and skills.

title: Resaerch Journey
text:
Work in Progress

Leveraging Multi-Field On-Farm Experiment Data: Externalities in Collected Data
(with D. Bullock and T. Mieno)
     - Examines the broader economic value and unintended effects of multi-field precision experiments
     - Demonstrates external validity using harmonized datasets across 100+ farms
    GitHub Repository
Evaluating the Profitability of Corn Seeding Decisions: Insights from On-Farm Precision Experiments Data (with D. Bullock and T. Mieno)
     - Estimates and validates growers’ input decisions and optimizes future recommendations
    GitHub Repository
Can On-Farm Subplot Experiments Improve Regional Nitrogen Decisions? A Distributional Perspective (with D. Bullock and T. Mieno)
     - Estimated higher moments and yield distributions using GAM and maximum entropy methods
     - Examine subplot data improves distribution estimates with uncertainty compared to aggregated data
    GitHub Repository
Informing Site-Specific Input Management in South Africa Using On-Farm Experimentation (with M. Delport, D. Bullock, and T.Mieno)
     - Led data management, reproducibility workflows, and statistical analysis across all projects

title: Jaeseok Hwang
text: During my research journey in graduate school (MS and Ph.D. in Applied Economics), I developed a deep interest in Econometrics, Price Analysis, and Statistical Learning. This collection of essays showcases how I built my foundational knowledge and expanded my research focus. Please enjoy this material and feel free to contact me at jaeseok2@illinois.edu.

title: Jaeseok Hwang
text:
Welcome to My Personal Study Notes on Statistics! This webpage serves as a comprehensive repository for reviewing and updating the statistical knowledge I have acquired through my academic classes and research projects. Here, I aim to organize, refine, and expand on concepts that have been pivotal in my work as a researcher and student. ## License {.unnumbered}

title: Project and Research
text:
Publications

David S. Bullock, Taro Mieno, and Jaeseok Hwang (2020)
The value of conducting on-farm field trials using precision agriculture technology:
a theory and simulations. Precision Agriculture, 21, 1027–1044.
 Link to the published paper

title: Project and Research
text:
Work in Progress

1. The Value of Multiple OFPE Datasets as an Externality

Main Contribution:
Although current OFPE datasets are limited in both quantity and quality, this research progressively integrates key domain knowledge from crop growth models in agronomy and crop science. The goal is to reform traditional supervised learning models so they better align with the biological and economic mechanisms underlying yield response.
Objective:
Combine more than 100 OFPE (On-Farm Precision Experiment) datasets and implement a leave-one-location-out (LOLO) cross-validation to predict yields for a held-out field i where no training data exist.
Models:
XGBoost, Random Forest, and Causal Forest.
Key Findings / Limitations:

The predictive capability of trained models remains low across fields.

A “universal yield-N response” derived from the combined dataset has limited explanatory power due to heterogeneous data quality and scale.

Ongoing Work:
Shift focus from yield prediction toward improving the expected information gain and probabilistic profitability:

Identify available planting, application, and harvest windows.

Integrate core APSIM/DSSAT modules to simulate nitrogen uptake and mineralization processes.

Use ex-post yield and EONR (via backward induction) to evaluate stochastic profitability.





2. Profitable Seeding Decisions and Farmer Behavior

Main Contribution:
This study frames the dynamic risk environment faced by growers—capturing how weather and price volatility shape real-world decision-making and risk management behavior. It models how farmers adapt to uncertainty in both short- and long-term horizons.
Objective:
Compare producers’ chosen seeding rates with the economically optimal seeding rate (EOSR) and assess their profitability under historical vs. recent weather and price conditions.
Model:
Generalized Additive Model (GAM).
Key Findings:
Producers’ chosen rates are strongly influenced by historical weather and price trends, but recent shocks in weather or market conditions often lead to suboptimal outcomes.
Ongoing Work:
Develop a dynamic framework to evaluate how short- and long-term shocks in weather and prices affect producers’ adaptive decisions and profitability over time.




3. Enhancing the Value of Soil Information: Insights from OFPE

Main Contribution:
This research focuses on identifying strategies that help farmers enhance their learning capacity—both statistically and computationally—to improve long-run profitability through data-informed management decisions.
Status Quo:
Farmers often base N-rate decisions on soil sampling and simulator-based recommendations. However, single-rate applications offer limited learning potential compared to variable-rate (VRN) approaches supported by on-farm experimentation (OFE).
Research Question:
How effectively can we learn accurate yield-N response functions from soil information when combining VRN applications with OFE, compared to learning from single-rate applications?
Proposed Approach:
Develop and test statistical frameworks (TBD) to quantify the learning gain from spatially rich OFE data relative to conventional soil-test-based recommendations.





Other Collaborative Work

Informing Site-Specific Input Management in South Africa Using On-Farm Experimentation
(with M. Delport, D. Bullock, and T. Mieno)
    – Led data management, reproducibility workflows, and statistical analysis across all project sites.

title: Jaeseok Hwang
text:
Hi, I’m Jaeseok Hwang — an Applied Economist and Data Scientist completing my Ph.D. in Applied Economics at the University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign (expected May 2026).
My research develops data-driven decision systems for U.S. crop producers, integrating applied machine learning, Bayesian modeling, and economic optimization to turn limited field data into actionable, risk-aware insights.
Main focus on building profit-optimization and risk-management frameworks that connect crop producers information with ag-technology, input-supply — using R as my primary analytical environment and Python for scalable machine-learning workflows.
